layers.description: These data are updated regularly. Historic alignments have the original trail segment IDs except in a few cases. Historic trail segment IDs with a decimal in the .90s either had a different trail ID (not segment ID); others had a trail segment ID that matched one that was used in the 2006-2007 trail condition inventory. I didn't change the 2006-7 ID because it would be overly complicated to change all items relating to a new segment ID.

The streams and ditches in this dataset were conflated from various data sources, including NHD, Colorado Department of Natural Resources Division of Water Resources (CDSS), Boulder County, City of Boulder and individual ditch companies. The data was verified with field visits and extensive staff knowledge. The data includes links to various internal databases, as well as the Colorado Division of Water Resources database. Pre and Post 2013 Colorado Flood alignments are included. Flow directions for network analysis are also incorporated into the data. This data is appropriate for both small and large scale usage.

This data represents the centerlines of streets in the City of Boulder. Lines follow the center of each street and alley and are broken at intersections. Divided streets and highways are represented with a centerline for each direction to represent the dual carriageway. Street suffix abbreviations are modeled from the USPS standards. This data can be used to perform network analysis or for address geocoding. This data participates in a network (TRANS.STREETSNETWORK) with the TRANS.STREETS_ND_Junctions point feature class.

mxd.description: These data represent snow removal line and point data, updated for the 2016/2017 snow year to reflect the City of Boulder Transportation Snow and Ice Control Plan. These data include any line feature designated for snow removal, including: (1) street snow removal, described as Primary Routes, Primary and Secondary Routes, Secondary Routes, and Secondary Conditional Routes; and (2) bike system and sidewalk snow removal, described as Bike System Routes, Bike System Routes/Trackless Routes, Trackless Routes, and Hand Removal. The current dataset includes transit (bus) stops subject to snow hand removal, as described in the the RFP for Snow Removal Services received 09/2016. These data are for general reference purposes only, and should not be used for any travel planning. Information subject to change.

mxd.summary: Snow removal data for 2016/2017 snow year.
mxd.author: AME

layers.description: Transit stop inventory, maintenance, and condition status. Based on RTD data and city bus stop data, joined using BSID. Original data are collected using a handheld GPS unit and MS Excel. Developed for use with Collector for ArcGIS. Updated by GO Boulder and current as of Fall 2016.Each bus stop is evaluated based on criteria developed by GO Boulder. Inventory Details include: Inventory Status:Current status of inventory for a given stop. This is also the basis for the map symbols. May be flagged as “Inventory Needed” if the inventory is out of date, or if the stop is soon to be replaced.Concrete Pad (2 points): A concrete pad is usually in addition to the sidewalk, and provides a place for benches, trash cans, shelters, or other amenities to be located. Pads may be located in front of or behind the sidewalk (in the “tree lawn”).Concrete Curb (1 point):A concrete curb may exist even when there is no sidewalk or any other amenities. This is simply a traditional curb and gutter.Bike Rack (1 point): Bike racks must be located at the stop to provide a place to store a bike while on a transit trip. Sometimes they are provided by a nearby property owner.Trash Can (1 point):Trash cans must also be located right at the stop. Sometimes adjacent property owners will chain a trash can to the stop. Other times they are maintained and emptied by other parties. See photograph for more details.Shelter (3 points): Shelters are typically provided at the busiest bus stops and provide a place for passengers to wait under cover from rain and wind. They come in many designs, and from different eras. Older shelters may be beginning to show damage. See photos.Benches (2 points):Seating arrangements can also vary greatly depending on the stop. If a stop has seating provided that must be maintained by somebody, the stop scores 2 points for having benches.Score:The score is a cumulative out of 10 points, and is simply the sum of the various categories described above.Quality:This is a subjective rating. It takes into account wear and tear, age, damage, and subjective qualities like sidewalk access and lighting. See photographs to double-check the assessment of the quality of a stop.Rating 2010: Some stops were rated in an earlier Bus Stop Inventory effort. These scores are recorded in this category.Comments:This is a place for any additional comments or notes about a stop.Sidewalk Access:This is a subjective rating of the quality of sidewalk access. It takes into consideration things like nearby crosswalks being up-to-date on handicap access, cracks or weeds in the concrete, and the relative safety and comfort of accessing a stop from the sidewalk. This category can be ranked Good, Fair, or Poor.Lighting: Yes, or No. This is based on a quick glance at nearby streetlights. This may not always be 100% accurate due to inventories being taken during the daytime.Bus Stop Status: Active, Removed, Abandoned, Other, or Adopted.

These data represent snow removal line data, updated for the 2016/2017 snow year. The dataset includes any line feature designated for snow removal, including: (1) street snow removal, described as Primary Routes, Primary and Secondary Routes, Secondary Routes, and Secondary Conditional Routes; and (2) bike system and sidewalk snow removal, described as Bike System Routes, Bike System Routes/Trackless Routes, Trackless Routes, and Hand Removal [see field SNOWTYPE].Route information for Primary Routes is captured in fields SNOWRTE1, SNOWRTE2, SNOWRTE3, SNOWRTE4, and SNOWRTE5; while route information for Secondary and Secondary Conditional Routes is captured in the field SNOWRTE6_13. Bike System Routes are captured in SNOWBIKEPED; Trackless Routes are captured in SNOWTRACKLESS; and Hand Removal is captured in SNOWHANDLINE. Users should note that street snow removal routes overlap in several areas; similarly, Bike System Routes, Trackless Routes, and Hand Removal overlap frequently. All line features included in the snow removal system are indicated in field SNOWREMOVE, where VALUE == Y.Legacy snow removal data are located in an archive geodatabase: E:\GISMAPFILES\Transportation\Streets\Snow Routes. The current dataset was developed in Autumn 2016 with the aim of: (1) consolidating snow removal information into a minimum number of feature classes; (2) aligning snow information with existing GIS data for streets, bike paths, and sidewalks; and (3) updating snow route data to reflect the 2016/2017 City of Boulder Transportation Snow and Ice Control Plan and the RFP for Snow Removal Services received 09/2016. Major changes to snow route data include the revision of "Floater Routes" and "Residential Routes; new routes are described as Route 12 (Floater Routes north of Arapahoe Rd.); Route 12 Conditional (Residential Routes north of Arapahoe Rd.); Route 13 (Floater Routes south of Arapahoe Rd.); and Route 13 Conditional (Residential Routes south of Arapahoe Rd.). Minor revisions were made to bike system and sidewalk snow removal information, per maintenance staff request.Line features were digitized using the best available information. Street snow removal lines are primarily derived from SDE feature class "BASEMAP.GEOSTREETS," while bike system snow removal lines are based on SDE feature class "TRANS.BIKE_PED_SYSTEM." Sidewalk and crosswalk snow removal lines are derived from SDE feature class "BASEMAP.Planimetrics2014_Sidewalks." Occasional geometric modifications occur where necessary: bike system snow removal lines are modified to enhance connectivity; and sidewalk lines are split to accurately represent snow removal activities. Street lines received no geometric modification. Where no previously-digitized lines existed, snow removal lines were heads-up digitized based on 2014 DRCOG 6-inch aerial photography. Street features that not associated with snow removal are contained within the dataset to facilitate future revisions. The source dataset for each line is captured in field LINESOURCE; and ID_NUMBER serves as a key field to join to the sources.Note that lines from "BASEMAP.Planimetrics2014_Sidewalks" are significantly more precise/accurate than lines from "TRANS.BIKE_PED_SYSTEM." Planimetrics 2014 data should eventually replace trails and sidewalk connectors in both the master Bike Pedestrian System data and the current dataset.Future revisions should capture which departments, agencies, or organizations are responsible for each snow removal line segment.Metadata updated: October 2016.

Street snow removal lines are primarily derived from SDE feature class "BASEMAP.GEOSTREETS," while bike system snow removal lines are based on SDE feature class "TRANS.BIKE_PED_SYSTEM." Sidewalk and crosswalk snow removal lines are derived from SDE feature class "BASEMAP.Planimetrics2014_Sidewalks." Occasional geometric modifications occur where necessary: bike system snow removal lines are modified to enhance connectivity; and sidewalk lines are split to accurately represent snow removal activities. Street lines received no geometric modification. Where no previously-digitized lines existed, snow removal lines were heads-up digitized based on 2014 DRCOG 6-inch aerial photography. Street features that not associated with snow removal are contained within the dataset to facilitate future revisions. The source dataset for each line is captured in field LINESOURCE; and ID_NUMBER serves as a key field to join to the sources.Note that lines from "BASEMAP.Planimetrics2014_Sidewalks" are significantly more precise/accurate than lines from "TRANS.BIKE_PED_SYSTEM." Planimetrics 2014 data should eventually replace trails and sidewalk connectors in both the master Bike Pedestrian System data and the current dataset.Future revisions should capture which departments, agencies, or organizations are responsible for each snow removal line segment.Metadata updated: October 2016.

These data represent snow removal line data, updated for the 2016/2017 snow year. The dataset includes any line feature designated for snow removal, including: (1) street snow removal, described as Primary Routes, Primary and Secondary Routes, Secondary Routes, and Secondary Conditional Routes; and (2) bike system and sidewalk snow removal, described as Bike System Routes, Bike System Routes/Trackless Routes, Trackless Routes, and Hand Removal [see field SNOWTYPE].Route information for Primary Routes is captured in fields SNOWRTE1, SNOWRTE2, SNOWRTE3, SNOWRTE4, and SNOWRTE5; while route information for Secondary and Secondary Conditional Routes is captured in the field SNOWRTE6_13. Bike System Routes are captured in SNOWBIKEPED; Trackless Routes are captured in SNOWTRACKLESS; and Hand Removal is captured in SNOWHANDLINE. Users should note that street snow removal routes overlap in several areas; similarly, Bike System Routes, Trackless Routes, and Hand Removal overlap frequently. All line features included in the snow removal system are indicated in field SNOWREMOVE, where VALUE == Y.Legacy snow removal data are located in an archive geodatabase: E:\GISMAPFILES\Transportation\Streets\Snow Routes. layers.description: Transit stop inventory, maintenance, and condition status. Based on RTD data and city bus stop data, joined using BSID. Transit stop inventory, maintenance, and condition status. Based on RTD data and city bus stop data, joined using BSID. Original data are collected using a handheld GPS unit and MS Excel. Developed for use with Collector for ArcGIS. Updated by GO Boulder and current as of Fall 2016.Each bus stop is evaluated based on criteria developed by GO Boulder. Inventory Details include: Inventory Status:Current status of inventory for a given stop. This is also the basis for the map symbols. May be flagged as “Inventory Needed” if the inventory is out of date, or if the stop is soon to be replaced.Concrete Pad (2 points): A concrete pad is usually in addition to the sidewalk, and provides a place for benches, trash cans, shelters, or other amenities to be located. Pads may be located in front of or behind the sidewalk (in the “tree lawn”).Concrete Curb (1 point):A concrete curb may exist even when there is no sidewalk or any other amenities. This is simply a traditional curb and gutter.Bike Rack (1 point): Bike racks must be located at the stop to provide a place to store a bike while on a transit trip. Sometimes they are provided by a nearby property owner.Trash Can (1 point):Trash cans must also be located right at the stop. Sometimes adjacent property owners will chain a trash can to the stop. Other times they are maintained and emptied by other parties. See photograph for more details.Shelter (3 points): Shelters are typically provided at the busiest bus stops and provide a place for passengers to wait under cover from rain and wind. They come in many designs, and from different eras. Older shelters may be beginning to show damage. See photos.Benches (2 points):Seating arrangements can also vary greatly depending on the stop. If a stop has seating provided that must be maintained by somebody, the stop scores 2 points for having benches.Score:The score is a cumulative out of 10 points, and is simply the sum of the various categories described above.Quality:This is a subjective rating. It takes into account wear and tear, age, damage, and subjective qualities like sidewalk access and lighting. See photographs to double-check the assessment of the quality of a stop.Rating 2010: Some stops were rated in an earlier Bus Stop Inventory effort. These scores are recorded in this category.Comments:This is a place for any additional comments or notes about a stop.Sidewalk Access:This is a subjective rating of the quality of sidewalk access. It takes into consideration things like nearby crosswalks being up-to-date on handicap access, cracks or weeds in the concrete, and the relative safety and comfort of accessing a stop from the sidewalk. This category can be ranked Good, Fair, or Poor.Lighting: Yes, or No. This is based on a quick glance at nearby streetlights. This may not always be 100% accurate due to inventories being taken during the daytime.Bus Stop Status: Active, Removed, Abandoned, Other, or Adopted.
